summary.seg: This fragment, probably copied in the 14th century, is a surviving portion of a Menaion for April, a liturgical book containing the components of services particular to individual days of the year. The majority of the folios have been lost, and those that remain have become soft and fragile. The manuscript retains its original binding, but most of the leather covering material has been lost, while most of what survives has become detached, leaving the wooden boards and textile spine lining exposed. The manuscript is accompanied by a number of small paper fragments, including some originally belonging both to it and to at least three other liturgical manuscripts, two of which are probably of similar date while the other was copied in the late 15th century.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers 1-43, in pencil, in Arabic numerals, recto, upper right.
There is an earlier foliation of ff. 1-38 with the numbers 2-39, in pencil, in Arabic numerals, recto, upper right, which has subsequently been cancelled.
supportDesc.collation: Part I consists of 8 quires; the other parts are loose fragments: 18-7, 28-5, 38-5, 4-78, 88-4

binding.p: Textblock cut to the size of the boards.
There are four sewing stations. Preparation cannot be determined. Sewing is of loop stitch using an s-twist thread of medium thickness.

Classical Greek endbands extending approximately ¼ of the way onto the boards – sewn around two cord cores, the lower is diagonal and the upper is wound vertically. The tailband is largely complete but the headband only exists over the left board.
Transverse continuous textile spine lining, extending approximately 1/3 of the way onto the board. There are no endleaves.
Wooden boards with square edges apart from rounding at the spine edge which meets the textblock at the shoulder.
On the foredge of the left board, there is a hole that probably would have contained a metal fastening.
On the inner side of the right board are remnants of covering leather and two braided leather straps.

A deformed remnant of dark brown tanned skin covering remains attached to the right board, and a separate piece is housed alongside the manuscript, which is decorated with blind tooling. The tooling consists of a triple fillet at the edge of the board, then a vegetative roll, then a triple fillet border. Within this border triple fillets extend from the corners and centres to create an intersecting pattern. At the intersections of the triple fillets round intaglio tools have been used.

physDesc.accMat: The manuscript is accompanied by thirteen fragments of paper, at least one of which originates from this manuscript. Four more bearing text appear to originate from three other manuscripts, while the others contain small amounts of text or none at all. The manuscript is also accompanied by the surviving fragment of its binding's leather covering.

history.acquisition: Acquired between 1898 and 1900, as indicated by its placement in the accession register of the Additional manuscripts.

recordHist.source: Description of binding draws upon unpublished description prepared (2020) by Samuel Foley and Cecilia Diminuco, Dept of Conservation and Collection Care, Cambridge University Library.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

analytic.title: Hand-list of the additional Greek manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge

monogr.title: Scriptorium. Revue internationale des études relatives aux manuscrits

msItem.title: Menaion
msItem.note: Defective at the beginning and end, with lacunas: begins during the entry for 12 April, ends during that for 24 April
msItem.incipit: f. 1r ἀντὶ πάντων, χριστιανὸν ἑαυτὸν εἶναι

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 8 quires; those whose extent can be established with certainty are all quaternia. The reconstruction of the structure of the incomplete quires presented below is conjectural. An unknown number of quires may have been lost between Quires 1 and 2, probably two have been lost between Quires 2 and 3, and one has apparently been lost between Quires 7 and 8.

list.item: Quire 18-7 f. 1 Seven folios have been lost, with loss of text
Quire 28-5 ff. 2-4 The first and third-sixth folios have been lost, with loss of text
Quire 38-5 ff. 5-7 The first five folios have been lost, with loss of text
Quires 88-4 ff. 40-43 The first and sixth-eighth folios have been lost, with loss of text

supportDesc.condition: ff. 1, 4, 5 and 41 are detached, and many other folios are torn in the gutter and sometimes tenuously attached. Some folios have suffered losses from the edges and there are a few small holes. There is extensive water staining and the paper has become very soft and fragile. There is also black mould staining and areas of dirt.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 1r-43r A single column of 26 lines.
180 115

handNote.p: The manuscript was copied by Hand A, in mixed minuscule script, slanting slightly to the right, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size and some flourishing of tails into the margin.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear only at the end of lines or in the top line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings and nomina sacra strokes.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, question mark and full stop.
Headings are written in Alexandrine majuscule script in red ink.

physDesc.musicNotation: The text is accompanied by theta notation.

decoDesc.decoNote: Sections begin with minor initials in red ink.
Divisions between days are marked by simple vignettes in red ink.

physDesc.additions: There are occasional brief annotations in Greek in the margins, in various hands.

history.origin: The manuscript was probably copied in the 14th century, as suggested by the style of script and the use of eastern paper.

msItem.title: Menaion
msItem.note: This is a detached portion of the main body of the manuscript; it is marked in pencil with the number 39.

layoutDesc.layout: Fragment F. 39 recto-fragment F. 39 verso A single column, originally of 26 lines. 180 115

handDesc.handNote: Fragment F. 39 recto-fragment F. 39 verso was copied by Hand A, the copyist of this manuscript.

decoDesc.decoNote: Sections begin with minor initials in red ink.

history.origin: This part belongs to the main manuscript, probably copied in 14th century.

msItem.title: Liturgical text
msItem.note: This is a fragment from a liturgical manuscript, containing stichoi.

support.material: Western paper, originally folded in folio. Watermark: Hat ( c. 76 c. 37 ) in the centre of the folio, similar to Harlfinger Chapeau 25. This example is dated to 1489.

layoutDesc.layout: Fragment F. 1* Two columns of at least 27 lines.

handNote.p: Fragment F. 1* was copied by Hand B, in mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear only at the end of lines. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to nomina sacra strokes.
There are inclusions of letters within omicron
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points and full stop.

decoDesc.decoNote: Sections begin with minor initials in red ink.

history.origin: The manuscript from which this fragment comes was probably copied in the late 15th century, as suggested by the watermark. This is consistent with the style of script.

msItem.title: Liturgical text
msItem.note: This is a fragment from a liturgical manuscript, containing stichoi and Gospel lections.

layoutDesc.layout: Fragment F. 2* A single column of at least 16 lines.

handNote.p: Fragment F. 2* was copied by Hand C, in mixed minuscule script, upright or slanting slightly to the left, in brown ink, with modest variation in letter size.
Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points.

decoDesc.decoNote: Sections begin with minor initials in red ink.

history.origin: This manuscript from which this fragment comes was probably copied in the 13th or 14th century, as suggested by the style of script and the use of eastern paper.

msItem.title: Liturgical text
msItem.note: These are small fragments from a liturgical manuscript.

layoutDesc.layout: Fragments 3* - 12* The manuscript from which the two largest of these fragments came had at least 13 lines.

handNote.p: The two largest fragments were copied by Hand D, in mixed minuscule script, upright or slanting slightly to the right, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size.
Breathings are round. There is accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to nomina sacra strokes.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points.

decoDesc.decoNote: Sections begin with minor initials in red ink.

history.origin: The manuscripts from which the fragments come were probably copied in the 14th century, as suggested by the style of script and the use of eastern paper.

surface.n: right cover, outer with covering reversed

pb.n: right cover, outer with covering reversed
